Title: I ate the swans
Content:
The work was created as part of a residency in the village of Muzychi.
 The text on the artwork: "I ate the swans because they have a
 
 home"
 On the territory of the house in the village of Novosilky, where we lived for two weeks, there was a pond with a small house on the surface of the water for the two swans that lived there. After several days of conscientiously observing these birds, I felt a sense of dissonance between their calmness and my inner emptiness, because they have a home and I don't. I don't have it because it was taken away (I'm talking about Luhansk, occupied in 2014). They, in their close attachment to the place, seemed integral, inextricably linked to the space that surrounded them.
 I was deprived of my home. Now I am looking for a new one. But the feeling that I am in my place is not there, no matter how much I search. Is it even possible to find another home? And if it is, will my old wound ever heal?
 The act of swallowing swans becomes a metaphor for this desire to find a home. Envy of the swans, who have what I lack, makes me want to eat them. Perhaps by absorbing the idyll of those who have not lost their home, I will understand where mine is? This work opened up a new meaning for me: by eating the swans, they settled in me - not finding my home, I became it myself
Other material: Paper, watercolor, ink, acrylic, colored pencils
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: This work explores the theme of searching for a sense of belonging and home, the search for a safe place. Through the image of a self-portrait consuming swans, I depict my longing to find what I lack — a home, a familiar place, which I was deprived of in childhood due to the Russian occupation. The swans symbolize attachment to a place, idyll, and belonging, all of which I have lost. By consuming them, I try to understand how to find a new home, and ultimately realize that, even without a physical home, I myself become a shelter — the swans have settled within me.

Title: Boy George
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Kathy creates work inspired by her musical heroes, in this case, Boy George. Kathy says she listens to music at home and she likes to listen to music with friends, it makes her feel sad and happy.

Title: As You Find Me
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
Rehabilitated from traumatic brain injury, I have lived and created this home. My shelter as an outsider, a brain injury survivor, home-made artist.
 
 Since my TBI this shelter has afforded and demanded of me. A multitude of inputs that have stretch and expanded my possibilities creatively over time, across the duration of my stay. The creative explorations, investigations, adventures, formed from many found objects. My artistic idea’s, struggles, execution and achievements.
 
 This has offered shelter; to exhibitions, both mine and others. Hosting various themed parties over my time here.
 
 Demonstration.
 
 Upcycled, recycled.
 
 Tended.
 
 Overloaded.
 
 Abused.
 
 Uplifted.
 
 This film is a summary of my life here. My shelter studio and workshop. The views, artworks and vista’s it has offered. My shelter as an Outsider’s Inside.

Title: Refuge in the Depths
Content: Refuge in the Depths is my exploration of solitude and sanctuary within the confines of a deep rock chasm. Inspired by the historical and spiritual significance of Lud's Church in Staffordshire, I wanted to create an immersive experience that invites viewers to step into a hidden world of quiet reverence. Using Virtual Reality, I sculpted a 360 degree environment that captures the towering rock walls, the softness of the moss and the dappled light and shadows. For me, this piece is about more than the physical space, its about the emotional refuge that places like this can provide; the comfort, the memories. I wanted to suggest the presence of the medieval community that sought safety and solace here without resorting to the obvious or the cliché. Every detail is meant to evoke that sense of quiet resilience and spiritual depth inviting viewers to reflect on the weight of history and the human need for sanctuary.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Refuge in the Depths explores solitude and sanctuary within a deep rock chasm, inspired by the historical and spiritual essence of Luds Church. Built in Tilt Brush VR, the 360-degree artwork immerses viewers in towering rock walls, mossy textures, and dappled light. It evokes the quiet reverence of medieval congregations who sought solace here. Beyond the VR experience, stills, video, and large-scale projections offer glimpses into this hidden world, emphasizing themes of resilience and sanctuary. The soundscape deepens the emotional and historical connection for viewers. A video could guide viewers through the virtual space, combining visual transitions with ambient soundscapes to evoke the chasm’s historical and spiritual significance. Both formats help convey the artwork’s message to a wider audience, highlighting its emotional depth and narrative elements. *Vimeo link*

Title: Wildfire
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: This is a print from my zine about the environment and global warming.\n Josh has created a zine about Global Warming and how it is changing the world we live in. Josh wants to raise awareness of this problem and how the world is changing. He feels anxious about the changes that take the safety and shelter that our world provides away.

Title: Tin Jan: Work and Wheeze (in progress)
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: I've been making artwork since the 1970s about my lived experience as a woman who had had asthma since her babyhood, growing up in the smogs of South East London. Now aged 74, with my health at its worst, I've begun to collate and deepen my collection of life-work. Although my body is 70% medication, I've been protected by the medication, kept alive by it and it's been my 'armour', sheltering me from harm. However, its also been responsible for most of my other conditions - hypertension, diabetes, coeliac disease, arthritis and a stomach that's now risen to my chest cavity squashing my lung (which doesn't work at the best of times). This work illustrates my conditions. The heart is at the centre of this work, because it the heart is full of lovely heroes who have emotionally protected and sheltered me, influenced and brought me joy.

Title: My Mum From Ghana
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: This is my mum, I made it, I love my mum, she was from Ghana. My mum died from Covid, I had covid and my legs were very painful.\n Deborah lived with her mum and during the pandemic both her and her mum became ill with covid 19. Deborah's mum sadly passed away. Deborah now lives with her sister and processes her mothers death by creating artwork about her. This piece was inspired by the Ghanaian tradition of creating Nsodie's (terracotta heads of deceased women of importance).

Title: Friends
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: This is me and my friends, I love being with my friends and listening to music and dancing.\n Emma feels happiest when she goes out to discos with her friends, they are her shelter, her happy place.

Title: The A Team
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Leslie Thompson creates artwork about his family and memories of his time spent with them, especially his late mum. Leslie spent a lot of time reading comics and watching popular tv. He would then draw his memories of these. Drawing and these memories are Leslie's happy place.\n 'The A-Team from America still alive are watching the king Prince Charles on the balcony of Buckingham Palace with Camilla waving to the crowds in London. On the old tv. ' written by Leslie Thompson.

Title: untitled
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Ahmed Mohammed is non verbal artists who is supported by Venture Arts. Ahmed takes great enjoyment from creating artwork, this is his happy place.

Title: Beautiful Brain
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
Months after working on this art the suggesstion to submit this to the Shelter exhibition came to me in a dream.
 Looking back at this drawing again I realised it was symbolic of the sensory overload and isolation I have endured throughout my life.
 
 Working on this artwork provided shelter for me. It gave me a sence of calm and focus at a time when this could not be achieved in other areas of my life.

Title: Turkey
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Caryn lives with her sister in Manchester, but once a year goes to Turkey to stay with her brother and his family. This is the highlight of Caryn year and she enjoys making artwork about her time there. This book is collaged and stitched. Turkey is her happy place.

Title: A light passed, the moon on her side
Content: The autumn arrives, in orange hues reflecting of the skin, like a mask it covers, the leaves fall and reveals the naked, stems are left bare, bodies hang in a slight shiver, there a crunch, the leaves dead, the sound tasteful, my barefoot in yellow grounded, like the sun on the floor,
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: I find shelter in nature, where is can carry the weight of the things that linger in my body. In the autum i lay on the leaves like a bed, i sleep and rest and cry into soil, watering anything that alive before winter, the trees ground my feet, the branches shelter my body, the wind allows words to escape, the words that sometimes are held in homes, it pulls it out from my throat and carries it away with flies.

Title: HOME – The Most Dangerous Place for Women to Be
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: This piece explores feelings around safety, nurture and belonging, with home for me about being part of a community of trusted people, connected to our environment, rather than in isolation. This textile and mixed media piece, created entirely from recycled materials, reflects the importance of our basic needs for shelter, warmth, nurture and safety. A velvet cloud-like structure (not fully shown) represents the enveloping, holding feelings of nurture, protection, safety. Partially hidden from the world, the houses are separate, yet connected, private but accessible and capture a nostalgic sense of the past and present. Fantastical flowers root the building within its environment and provide relief like they do in a mental health crisis. The colour palette and title: HOME – The Most Dangerous Place for Women to Be is a stark reminder of how women globally are more likely to be exposed to

Title: Water Bears Don’t Die
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: My painting is of a tardigrade or water bear, the toughest thing alive! My images shows one of these creatures on a torn and dark canvas board surviving amidst chaos. As a person who struggles with multiple disabilities I think of the tardigrade’s resilience to help me get through the day.

Title: The Kitchen
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Bilal is due to get married, with his wife moving over to England to live with him. He created a series of embroidered artworks about getting the home ready for his new wife, creating shelter for her.

Title: Little Mix Mums
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Rhea has a very special relationship with her mum and with music, with Little mix being her favourite band. Rhea created this piece about her favourite things her mum and Little Mix, both together make her happy place.

Title: untitled

Title: Following
Content: ‘Following’ is part of my ongoing dialogue following my late in life ADHD diagnosis.\n They say there are five stages of grief: denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance. I am finding I oscillate between anger and depression, struggling to come to terms with the ashamed I feel for my younger self and the person I am now. Through making this artwork I found some shelter where I was able to meet and challenge the ‘monster’ on my back that is ADHD. This became one of the ways I found of greeting the person I was, with love, and finding a path towards acceptance of who I am now.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Following’ is part of my ongoing dialogue following my late in life ADHD diagnosis.\n \n They say there are five stages of grief: denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance. I am finding I oscillate between anger and depression, struggling to come to terms with the ashamed I feel for my younger self and the person I am now. Through making this artwork I found some shelter where I was able to meet and challenge the ‘monster’ on my back that is ADHD. This became one of the ways I found of greeting the person I was, with love, and finding a path towards acceptance of who I am now.

Title: Abode
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
A Section 27 No Fault Eviction launched me into the abyss of flat hunting in a city tha
 
 became 'London by the Sea'. A hard market on its own terms, lacking regulation and
 
 with competition on all levels, becomes my world. My world is precipitated to all
 
 things ‘housing'. I feel vulnerable and un-safe and can get lost in translation with all
 
 the formalities. After a period of housing instability I realise I've lost my home.
 
 'Abode' ignites questions regarding the difference between a 'house' and a 'home', the
 
 latter implying a feeling that's not part of the former'. The first relates to the structura
 
 and formal issues of living in a house such as having furniture. It's needed for a
 
 'home' to exist. Through collage and mixed media, using flat-pack furnitur
 
 instructions, a canvas, textiles and a vacuum storage pack, the work acknowledges
 
 the need for 'home' as well as its complexities

Title: Shelter
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Going to my woodland is my solace, when I was ill I ran away to my woodlands to get some peace away from hospital. I go camping when I’m there and I sometimes put up hammocks for sleeping in. When I’m there I feel like god is with me in the woods, it is my shelter.\n \n For this sculpture I’ve used hazel from woodlands, willow, hard board and brass. I’ve used a leather tarp with ringlets. This is a representation of me camping. I am the figure under the tarp which is made from keyring holders. The lack of keys represent the fact that I didn’t have or need any keys at this time.

Title: Rest in Peace
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: My daughter Tivoli passed away in violent circumstances. She wrote this poem aged 10. This competition has given me an opportunity to paint a tribute to her. The shelter that was not given her in her final moments on earth. "Hear my voice

Title: The Medieval Brigand'
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: The artwork represents myself at the age of 20 and the nine years I spent living in a traditional gypsy bender tent whilst travelling the country from county to county harvesting seasonal crops as an itinerant agricultural labourer whilst living in a travelling commune. The artwork includes the entirety of my possessions during this period which consisted mainly of tools and items essential to living in a temporary shelter which would be set up, lived in for a matter of weeks before being taken down, moved and set up again. I constructed the shelter from a frame made of hazel saplings, a plastic tarpaulin was used as a ground sheet with a canvas tarpaulin as a top sheet with another plastic tarpaulin as a top cover. My bed was set atop two pallets and my heat was supplied by a wood burning stove I made from an old oil can.

Title: Reincarnated Unborn Eve'
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: This painting is inspired by becoming a dad. At the time my partner was pregnant and we were both hoping we would have twins. I hoped it would be two boys called Ron and Don. I represented them as two different types of Sun. I believed that would be a way of identifying my two sons through their different brightness and warmth. Both equally as bright but one yellow-gold and the other orange-gold. I represented them as two fire arms, one automatic fire arm and the other a rifle. Representing their quickness as adult men. There is also the fruit that only exists in Sierra Leone, an apple that resembles the Adam’s apple of a man. And a grandfather clock which represents the memories I have of my grandfather, few houses in Sierra Leone still have grandfather clocks in them but they represent masculinity.

Title: Stable
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
As a choirboy I sang many carols.
 
 This is one of my first collages, continuing with the use of triangles that dominated my paintings over the preceding few years. I wanted to incorporate the green gold angel figures I had previously painted and fill the night sky with movement.
 
 Its worth remembering that at the heart of this story lies temporary shelter for people who are on a journey. How many people across the world are living in temporary shelter today?

Title: The Golden Bough
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
My ceramic fungi sculptures explore the profound themes of shelter and solace. Inspired by the vital role fungi play in our natural world, I aim to evoke a sense of tranquillity and wonder. These organisms, often hidden beneath the forest floor, provide essential shelter and sustenance for countless creatures. Through my work, I invite viewers to contemplate the importance of finding refuge and community in a chaotic world.
 
 By crafting intricate ceramic forms that mimic the diverse shapes and textures of fungi, I explore the multifaceted nature of shelter. These sculptures serve as both physical and symbolic representations of protection, growth, and resilience. Through my work, I seek to create a space for reflection and contemplation, inspiring a greater appreciation for the natural world and the importance of finding refuge.
